option.name: TOOL_WINDOW_CONFIGURED_FILTER
option.value: Show only selected application

list.name: Default
list.comment:
Correctly pass Context to AccountManagerHelper
- Update SDK and compilation sources to API 24 (Android 7.0 Nougat) - Pass Context to `AccountManagerHelper` - Reorder the arguments passed to `DownloadFileTask`
In the previous version, `AccountManagerHelper` relied on a context saved in `MainActivity` to run. This broke when a background sync was triggered, because the app was no longer open and thus the context was inaccessible. In this version, the context is retrieved from the sync adapter and sent to the account manager. In other places where the account manager was used, the context is now correctly passed to it natively. This is the more sensible way of running the code.
I have left the `context` field in `MainActivity` because certain classes still rely on it. However, none of these classes need to run in the background and should always be able to access MainActivity's context, so I don't see any harms arising. This will obviously be fixed before a full release.

task.summary: Default task

Migrate project to Android Studio 2.0
Also, a totally refreshed laptop and install of all of this.
Also, it's really late.
:)

Follow some best practices
- Reorganise some project folders - Reformat XML files

Reorganise, Rearrange, Reformat
I've decided I'm never going to be able to handle the mess that some of these classes feel like, but I decided over the past couple hours to fix a few of them a little bit. It's just nicer to be writing code that's properly formatted and is easy to use.
So in this spirit, I: - Renamed a bunch of classes - Enabled automatic reformatting and rearranging - Set up rules for reformatting - Split a few classes into easier subclasses - Used one logical task per subroutine (at least, in RecursiveColumnUpdater)
Also, these commits should now be automatically GPG-signed on GitHub. Provided the kinks are ironed out (which they... should be?)

Change line length to 100
The longer line lengths don't work so well on smaller screens. These changes make that happen, and also reformat every line of code in the program that I want to use. Now the code is nicer!

Open MainActivity once logged in
It was weird and annoying that sync didn't start once the user had logged in. But it's okay now, we fixed that, by adding an `OnActivityResult` function. This code should change in the future.

Fix recursive loop
- Recursively update child counts - (Temporarily) remove next tasks, and hasChildren attributes - Change some code style settings - Add database helper method for retrieving integers
It turns out counts of children are recursively defined (i.e. they're the _total_ amounts underneath a tree item). So large tracts of `RecursiveColumnUpdater` had to be rewritten, which took a long time. Seriously, though, this took a lot longer than it looks like.

Add `blocked`, `hasChildren` and `nextTask` to tree updater
- Track the next available task in each parent - Track `blocked` based on this - Set `blocked` on all items in dropped projects - Track `blockedByDefer` based on deferrals - Track `hasChildren` based on existing child counts - Make the database tree loop more efficient by using better SQL statements for cascading values - Fix `MainActivity` not noticing that `LoginActivity` has finished - General efficiency stuff in `RecursiveColumnUpdater` - Recursively fill `projectID`, a new column
A task is 'blocked' in OmniFocus if it can't be worked on right now, because it requires something before it to be completed, it has been dropped, or it's been deferred into the future. This commit tracks blocking through the OmniFocus database and updates columns appropriately.
It's harder than it looks. Lotta algorithm thinking involved. Luckily, I'm pretty hopeful that the algorithm stuff will die down for a bit, at least until I have to worry about editing and syncing again. Once I get onto the UI this gets a lot easier and a lot more fun. I hope.

Recursively update contexts
The next chapter in the Great Recursive Update Saga is updating contexts. A lot of this was pretty much the same stuff (and in some cases quicker/easier) as last time.
Speeds are also looking pretty goodthe whole process takes about 7.5 seconds, which is good for a recursive tree traversal like this.
This means the last thing I need to figure out is how to count the number of available items. That is, anything which isn't blocked, blockedByDefer, or on hold. Problem is, we're setting 'on hold' in the context updater, which requires the first loop to have run for its own counter. So we'll probably have to run another loop (contexts can be done in the existing one, probably) to fix it up.

Complete recursive updater
- Add data types to SQLite database - Fix `blocked` not filling down properly by separating it into a new loop - Count 'available' tasks (not blocked, deferred, on-hold) - Speed up project counting by separating it, also enabling 'available' counting - Remove a useless test for the size of a ContentValues that would always return true - Re-implement the boolean tracking of whether an item has children or not - Correctly fill down due dates, defer dates & flags - Correctly track project status and type as the loop fills down
And that's a wrap! I've checked out this update on my phone and everything (almost) is being appropriately tracked and counted, at least to the point that would satisfy any OmniFocus user who's game enough to use it on Android.
While updating and fixing this subroutine was a slog and a half, it's rewarding because it means I can finally get working on the UI and the important-yet-possible-easier bits of the application. Which is great for everyone!

Initialise data model
- Create data model for all data types except perspectives - Update Android Studio to 2.1, and a few SDK updates
I've decided that the way I'm going to sort everything out is to read a list of items from the database into their own classes (like an array), and display that list to the user through a RecyclerView (like a ListView).
To do that, I needed to build a proper model of all the classes which might be used. This model is totally incompletethere's lots of data types which might change as I discover new things which are more helpful for displaying data, and there's going to be a lot of helper methods added. But this way, I can have an array of contexts / tasks / folders / whatever to display to the user.

Create helper class for data model
To actually use the data model, we need classes that can convert database entries into instances of the data model's classes
In this commit, our class is able to, given a parent ID, return lists of children of different types of items (contexts, projects, folders) which can be used to populate various views.
Keep in mind that this is totally incomplete for the momentI need to add classes like an inbox getter and the likebut it'll do for building the views that we need.
- Add `DataModelHelper` - Add cursor-to-data-model methods - Add get-children-of methods - Add column lists to the database contract - Add `getLong()` and `getDate()` methods to the database helper class - Change the type of `projectID` in the Task class

Create basic list view
- Add list fragment - Add fragments for individual items - Add an adapter for a list of tasks
Wow!
We can check off the backend stuff as Done For Now, and move onto the more exciting frontend. With that in mind, I finally got over the ListView/RecyclerView hurdle and have built a list of items!
At the moment it just displays a basic list of tasks that have no parent (so top-level projects and things that haven't been deleted yet), but soon it'll do all the rest of stuff.

Display name and info in list rows
- Add exceptions for missing columns (for getString, etc) in DatabaseHelper - Return null if the date retrieved from the database is empty - Stop instantiating an empty array for blank selection arguments - Correctly retrieve certain Task columns from database (previously was retrieving the ID in place) - Add method for getting an ID:Name map for Contexts (used to get context names in the list view) - Correctly retrieve due date and context, and add them to the list view's rows - Reorganise a bunch of XML resource files
This commit mostly just adds fields for the due date and context into list view rows. This way, when looking a list of tasks, the user can get a sense of what they should be doing without having to go into each one.
There were also a few more backend changes. I spent quite a while looking at the context field, thinking it wasn't displaying them, until I realised I'd chosen a scope that wouldn't display contexts anyway. Regardless, I have it now displaying every single task in my system, and it handles the data volume (TESTING AND MAINTAINING THE SOLUTION) incredibly smoothly. Well done Android.

Fix row layout
- Add dividers to rows - Vertically center row content - Truncate lines that are too long - Properly align context & date text
(It's looking a lot nicer :) )

Add scrollbars to list
Also, change the list density to be a little wider (for now). It'll be a setting later.

Add a navigation drawer
That was like 200x more difficult than it should've been. I spent a number of hours trying to fix various layout and UI bugs, glitches and the like. It's really difficult but almost entirely necessary to support older versions of Android, which makes the job a lot more difficultyou can't just type in the simple classes and have them work.
Plus, Google are never really clear with what exactly is the best practice to use. You have to do about 15-30 mins of research before commencing anything, which hurts a little. But it's well worth it.
At the end of this process I've built a nav drawer. It's something I can interact with in the app. It's really satisfying. And soon I'll be able to press some of these buttons and have various views appear. And at that point it'll be looking a lot closer to complete.
There actually isn't all that much left to go on this project, really. I can see it being done by August if I put the time in. That's a good feeling.
No changelog because I need to sleep.

Change theme and menu item color in nav drawer
If you open up Google Inbox on your phone, you'll notice the icons in the side menu are coloured, and when you press on them, their highlight colours reflect that. This is actually not something which Android likes to advertise it can do and it's not a default.
To work with this, I had to create a 'ColorStateList', which is a dictionary of different item states (focused, selected, checked, etc.) and corresponding colours. Once someone selects an item in the sidebar, all of the colours change to that item's colur, but only this item is selected so you only see it change.
For good measure, we also change the app's themethat means its accent colours and the rest. Next stop is to change the toolbar at the top of the app, and we can apparently animate it! Exciting!

Theme up the navigation
- Colour app bar and status bar, and transition them according to the currently selected item - Lighten the background highlight on the currently selected item
Took a lot longer than you might think, because it's really confusing to deal with status bars and the rest. I first experimented with setting a padding on the toolbar at the top of the screen, but this messed things up when I turned on immersive mode/expanded desktop.
The way to solve it, eventually, was to transition the colours with the toolbar. Apparently Android can take care of the status bar colour just fine without you having to set a darker variant. The other thing to remember was that I had to call `drawerLayout .invalidate()` _after_ I set the status bar colour, to refresh the view.

Implement perspective switching
- Add a flexible `getContexts()`, `getFolders()` and `getTasks()` method for retrieving entries from the database given specified selections and arguments - Re-implement current data model getters using this function - Add getters for tasks that're currently in the inbox, are top level projects, or flagged - Rename `TaskAdapter` to `ListAdapter`, and adapt it to any item (not just tasks) (semi-done) - Vary the items picked up by the ListFragment depending on arguments passed by the calling function (will need to change again for nested lists) - Set up toolbar and navbar in `MainActivity` in their own subroutines - Switch between fragments on menu item selection - Show a progress spinner in the interim - Correctly set `colorAccent` for the spinner colour
The navigation menu from previous updates now does more than just change the colour, it changes between different OmniFocus perspectives, as represented by android Fragments (like a cross between a View and an Activity). Effectively, when you click on an item in the sidebar, the current view will fade out, a progress spinner will fade in, and then fade out again when the new Fragment is ready to show up.
One of the bigger problems with this was working out the UX that Google uses in their Inbox app, which switches fragments and uses a coloured toolbar in a similar way. By default when switching fragments, you switch immediately on press, which is a jarring and non-animated transition. It's also really laggy.
Instead, I realised that Google fade out on click, and fade in once the drawer has closed (while also displaying a spinner as it loads the content). This solution seemed to work fairly well for me, and it creates a smooth and comfortable transition between views.
The next steps are a little more confusing: I need to be able to implement composite lists of Tasks, Contexts and Folders, and display them in each contextright now it breaks when we select 'Contexts' and doesn't show top-level Folders. This will be a challenge, particularly because they have to use the same adapter for the whole list, but I'm sure I'll figure it out (more like, I _have_ to figure it out).

Rewrite selections with string constants
Following the practices outlined in the SDD course, I replaced a lot of hardcoded strings in the Data Model Helper with constants that hold their string content. This means it's easier to write new code in this module, and also make changing something in the code very easy.

Allow different types of view in list
- Rename 'Entry' to 'Entries' in the database contract to avoid conflict - Add some more SQL shorthands to the data model helper - Get a readable database instead of a writable one when all we need to do is read from it (in the data model) - Generalise all returns from the data model to `List<Entry>` - Add the 'No Context' context to the list of top level contexts - Add a `getTopLevelFolders()` method to the data model - Add folders to the `getTopLevelProjects()` method - Update folder child counts in the RecursiveColumnUpdater - Update the available children count in the context updater - Implement `Comparable` in `Entry`, which compares by rank - Extract ViewHolders for Tasks, Folders and Contexts - Implement multiple ViewTypes and corresponding logic in the List Adapter - Add Due Soon and Overdue backgrounds to the Task list item - Oh man
So I know this requires a huge explanation, but it's almost 1am and I need to get some sleep. Plus, I don't think I can write and make much sense at the same time right now. But let's give it a try because I wanna be done with this for the weekend.
Because OmniFocus mixes its lists up, such that we can often see a Folder and a Task in the same list, we also need to mirror this functionality on Android. It's crucial that we can see everything the same way.
On Android, all we have to do is implement different View Types in the RecyclerView, which helps us instantiate new ViewHolders as we need them, with different types depending on what we want to display. In the ListAdapter, we look ahead (using the object's position) at what type it'll be, and generate a ViewHolder based on that, using one of the lovely views and classes we have.
In future, this will need to adapt to whether the task has children or is a project or whatnot, too. Keep an eye out.
Once this is done, it's not too difficult to just take a list of entries, split them up by type, and add each type to the ViewHolder it wants dynamically. Which is what we do.
The problems struck, I think, when I wanted to implement new things, like Folders. The chief one I dealt with just then was getting the folders to display counts of their children. This is tricky because of the rules around folders and projects:
1. A folder can hold other folders 2. A folder can hold projects 3. Projects cannot hold other projects
So the way to solve this while maintaining some efficiency was to have each project update its parent's (which must be a folder or nothing) child counts with its own. But we do this with a simple dictionary of folder IDs and child counts. Then, we iterate through each item in that dictionary and do the same until there are none left, adding items along the way. Finally, we take each ID in that list and update its child counts in the database.
This saves energy because we don't have to count any new items, just push old counts up the stack. There's probably a quicker way to do it. I don't care right now; I need to sleep. Have a nice weekend.

Add empty state
When a list is empty, it's important to let the user know the app hasn't broken and is just showing them an empty view. For that reason, we use empty statesplaceholder views in the background of the list, which are activated if there aren't any list items.
The new code checks the numbers of items in the RecyclerView on creation, and if that number is 0, then it displays a pretty simple logo and message to let the user know. The UI on this section isn't final, but it likely won't change before the submission date.

Add rows for projects and nested tasks
In OmniFocus, projects and nested tasks (i.e. tasks with child tasks) should display differently, because they're containers of tasks instead of tasks themselves, and display in different contexts (this time, I use 'context' in the traditional English sense).
A project displays exactly like a folder, with a 'remaining' count + an 'overdue' and 'due soon' count. The code is pretty much cut-and-paste and isn't going to change for the moment, but I kept it separate because I think they'll need to be separate things in the future.
A nested task displays like a hybrid of the two, with an 'x remaining' counter but also a due date. For this reason, I cut off the overdue/due soon counters because they'd fill the view. When I re-implement them, I'll likely structure it like the iOS OmniFocus app, which uses dots.
Finally, I also moved the ViewHolder binding classes (i.e. setting up the fields with the given task/context/folder) into the ViewHolders themselves, which cleans up `ListAdapter`.

Fix date view problems in Nested Task Holder
Only, I wish they were the only problems. At the very least, I'm gonna have to rewrite the `RecursiveColumnUpdater`, because I'm struggling with hierarchical database structures and it turns out I actually need to count all the children of every object anyway.

Made the recursive column updater more hacky
But hey, at least it works, right? Also, I threw in some buttons to synchronise and refresh the database in the top toolbar for good measure/easy access. They're buggy and will freeze up your UI, but they're there.

Discolour unavailable tasks
In normal OmniFocus, the user wants to be able to skim-read a list and understand as much as they can, because they're a power user and love that sort of stuff. This is why a task that isn't 'available' (i.e. blocked or completed) is greyed out, which is what I just did.
Now onto traversing the big list of tasks/projects/contexts/folders!

Enable full tree traversal
- Add methods to `DataModelHelper` for getting the appropriate children of an entry - Allow 'No Context' to be selected and displayed - Add a new initialiser to `ListFragment` that appropriately gets the data for an individual item - Reenable `OnListFragmentInteractionListener` and implement - Enable touch ripples in the RecyclerView, and convert margins to padding to suit - Use `FragmentTransaction.replace()` instead of removing, to remove all fragments - Change the default theme in `MainActivity` to the red theme (given that most users will start on the Forecast perspective, and not need to see the transition from purple.
The basic viewing app is almost complete! I've come a _long_ way today in putting this together, and now the user can entirely traverse the project and context treesstarting from the base elements and reaching whatever they need to (provided it isn't completed, in which case it's hidden).
The only real step I need to take now is to build the detail views in the list, and I'll have a rudimentary but fully-functional viewer app. Then I'll have to worry about editing, then syncing back up, so what I've decided is that from here I'll try to skip the little details, like animations between screens and fancy colouring, until the app is complete. I don't need those UI flourishes for the assessment, but I will need them for market, and I'm lucky that those are two separate stages in this process.
So I'm going to try and do as much as I can, as quickly as I can, and then move onto the filling in the fancy details later.

Add header rows to child views
Child View: Anything that isn't top-level, i.e. showing the children of a parent Header Row: A row displaying the currently selected parent as an item which can then itself be edited when you tap on it
- Edit sorting logic for Entries to accommodate for header rows - Move ViewHolders - Fade out inactive contexts - Add internal documentation to ViewHolder bindings

Optimise ViewGroup hierarchy
In Android, it's a bad idea to have a lot of ViewGroups as children of each other in a neverending stack extending forever into eternity and the abyss. This is just a quick patch that removes a couple of the poorly-developed layouts and aligns everything according to best practices.

Create basic Detail View
# Important Update I've decided that for the purposes of this assignment, I'm not going to complete a fully syncing OmniFocus application, just a viewer. The whole thing is going to take up far too much of my time, and I won't be able to get that done by August without failing the rest of my subjects.
From now until the due date, I'm going to complete the detail viewer, and add a notification system. I'll also need to implement an automatic syncing routine with that, and there'll probably be other stuff on the way. Once that's done, I'll add some simple finishing touches, and complete the rest of the project once school's out.
It's been really fun so far and I'm looking forward to where this is going. It doesn't just look like a sample project anymore, but instead it really feels like an app I'd use on a semi-regular basis. Once I get some more stuff into it, hopefully that'll only get stronger.
# Changelist - Make all data model items Parcelable - Appropriately handle null dates in the parceling process with new methods - Rename the various fields in the `ViewHolder`s to `entry` - Add a `DetailActivity` for displaying task/context/project details - Change the colour of `DetailActivity`'s app bar depending on where it was launched from (to maintain visual continuity). - Replace `EditText` with `TextInputEditText` for better support - Perform null checks for UI elements - Get the toolbar and drawer layout in `MainActivity` if they're null - Colour the `TextInputLayout` in the toolbar of `DetailActivity` appropriately
# Explanation This change took significantly longer than it needed to. The main reason for this is the way that Android messes around with the status bar and app layouts. Suffice to say I was not happy.
In a `DrawerLayout`, Android appropriately determines that you want the navigation drawer to display underneath the status bar, and extends the UI below it appropriately. This extension includes the toolbar.
Inexplicably, it doesn't do this for any other type of layout. So I spent a few hours trying to figure out what was actually going on with my UI, which was difficult because I had no idea what to search for and my internet was slow because I'd inadvertently downloaded a botnet. Or maybe it was just slow because it slows down sometimesI'm really not sure.
The solution, eventually, was to set the background colour of the view to be the same as the toolbar, so it looks like the toolbar extends below the status bar. Then we set the background of the rest of the view (underneath the toolbar) to be the normal android background (which I think is white). That way, we get the same effect as before, but without having to define a new status bar colour (because it doesn't tint your colours automatically).

Fix small bugs
- Fix a crash where `ViewHolder`s had null entries - Pass the Theme ID to the `DetailActivity` instead of the Menu ID - Make the `DetailActivity`'s toolbar hint depend on the type of entry being shown - Disable editing of the name text

Flight of the Navigator
# Changelog - Add methods for getting context and project names (given ids) - Add new fields to `Task` for context and project names - Fill those fields with the methods - Remove deprecated and messy `getContextNameMap()` function - Add a fragment to the `DetailActivity` to display a list of details - Vary the contents of this fragment depending on the type being shown - Rename a bunch of icons - Make the 'refresh' and 'server' icons white to fit - Add a huge number of layouts for the `DetailFragment`
# IT WORKS! :D After what I'm pretty sure is actually 12 hours of programming today, I think we've legitimately completed a fully-functional OmniFocus navigator. In effect, so long as you don't mind not seeing notifications, notes, attachments and a detailed understanding of the repetitions of the task, and you're happy to manually synchronise it, you can fully browse your OmniFocus library on Android.
Provided you get the .apk off me (which I'm happy to distribute once I figure out howI think there are a few OmniFocus users with Android in our class who might be interested).
Not less than half a day after deciding I was going to cut the project short, I've pretty much met 90% of my target. That's exciting.
Tomorrow, once I've slept, I'll post some screenshots or a video or something. It's looking really nice, and I put a fair bit of attention to detail into this latest list.
:sushi:

Implemented decryption
For this update, I wrote an OmniFocus file decrypter based on the mdoel that OmniGroup wrote in Python. It took a number of days and was one of the heftier parts of the project, particularly considering I had little idea on how to use Java in the ways I wanted to.
But, eventually, we got there. This update adds a number of minor UI changes (including the removal of the `Nearby` menu item, since it's no implemented), and the addition of this routine. It's not perfect and will probably throw errors and have a number of security holesand let's just hope nobody tries to use it with an older version of OmniFocusbut it works for my database on various phones/tablets so that should do for now.

Move sync to background, rewrite parser
The synchronisation loop has been moved out of its original class and into a `SyncAdapter`, which is a more appropriate Android loop and allows us to correctly handle synchronisation (instead of manually / called whenever I want it called). This was basically the last step of this project, once I add the stuff that gets it calling the sync loop automatically, and displaying a spinner on MainActivity whenever the user is syncing.
Also, when doing that, I found that the XML parser was broken. Instead of trying to save XMLPullParser, which is honestly the most horrifying tool I've had to use during this project, I switched to the w3c DOM classes, which work a lot betteralthough required a lot of finnicky rewriting. On top of that, Omni changed a lot of the sync types, which made this a lot harder. But lo, it was finished too.
Now to finish up syncing...

Swipe to refresh
- Add swipe to refresh spinner - Change spinner colour based on perspective - Add a sync broadcaster (to tell when syncs are done) - Show spinner if sync is in progress - Remove old menu icons for manual syncing - Change empty state text (better internal help)
In a moment, I'll set up automatic syncing using our background syncer. I'm impressed at how easy it is to use a sync adapter once it's been setup. These code changes were actually not that tiresome to implement, which is welcome.

SDD hand-in done
- Close leaking SQL cursors - Test for accounts before loading swipeLayout - Fix bug where recyclerView would stay invisible after load (took me AGES) - Update spinner if actively syncing - Send DetailActivity intents back to DetailActivity - Correctly send LoginActivity result to MainActivity - Correctly receive results and start sync - Register periodic syncs and turn on automatic syncs - Increase minimum SDK version to prevent untested code from working on old platforms
This should be the final version of the application before hand-in on 19/8. I've tested it on my phone and tablet running 5.1, and the new sync loop totally works. And it also lets the user know when we're syncing! Plus there's enough internal help to fill the requirements as far as I'm willing to go.
This is excitingas soon as I figure out how to export an APK, I'll upload it. Wouldn't hurt to test this.

Correctly pass Context to AccountManagerHelper
- Update SDK and compilation sources to API 24 (Android 7.0 Nougat) - Pass Context to `AccountManagerHelper` - Reorder the arguments passed to `DownloadFileTask`
In the previous version, `AccountManagerHelper` relied on a context saved in `MainActivity` to run. This broke when a background sync was triggered, because the app was no longer open and thus the context was inaccessible. In this version, the context is retrieved from the sync adapter and sent to the account manager. In other places where the account manager was used, the context is now correctly passed to it natively. This is the more sensible way of running the code.
I have left the `context` field in `MainActivity` because certain classes still rely on it. However, none of these classes need to run in the background and should always be able to access MainActivity's context, so I don't see any harms arising. This will obviously be fixed before a full release.

MESSAGE.value:
Display name and info in list rows
- Add exceptions for missing columns (for getString, etc) in DatabaseHelper - Return null if the date retrieved from the database is empty - Stop instantiating an empty array for blank selection arguments - Correctly retrieve certain Task columns from database (previously was retrieving the ID in place) - Add method for getting an ID:Name map for Contexts (used to get context names in the list view) - Correctly retrieve due date and context, and add them to the list view's rows - Reorganise a bunch of XML resource files
This commit mostly just adds fields for the due date and context into list view rows. This way, when looking a list of tasks, the user can get a sense of what they should be doing without having to go into each one.
There were also a few more backend changes. I spent quite a while looking at the context field, thinking it wasn't displaying them, until I realised I'd chosen a scope that wouldn't display contexts anyway. Regardless, I have it now displaying every single task in my system, and it handles the data volume (TESTING AND MAINTAINING THE SOLUTION) incredibly smoothly. Well done Android.

Fix row layout
- Add dividers to rows - Vertically center row content - Truncate lines that are too long - Properly align context & date text
(It's looking a lot nicer :) )

Add scrollbars to list
Also, change the list density to be a little wider (for now). It'll be a setting later.

Add a navigation drawer
That was like 200x more difficult than it should've been. I spent a number of hours trying to fix various layout and UI bugs, glitches and the like. It's really difficult but almost entirely necessary to support older versions of Android, which makes the job a lot more difficultyou can't just type in the simple classes and have them work.
Plus, Google are never really clear with what exactly is the best practice to use. You have to do about 15-30 mins of research before commencing anything, which hurts a little. But it's well worth it.
At the end of this process I've built a nav drawer. It's something I can interact with in the app. It's really satisfying. And soon I'll be able to press some of these buttons and have various views appear. And at that point it'll be looking a lot closer to complete.
There actually isn't all that much left to go on this project, really. I can see it being done by August if I put the time in. That's a good feeling.
No changelog because I need to sleep.

Change theme and menu item color in nav drawer
If you open up Google Inbox on your phone, you'll notice the icons in the side menu are coloured, and when you press on them, their highlight colours reflect that. This is actually not something which Android likes to advertise it can do and it's not a default.
To work with this, I had to create a 'ColorStateList', which is a dictionary of different item states (focused, selected, checked, etc.) and corresponding colours. Once someone selects an item in the sidebar, all of the colours change to that item's colur, but only this item is selected so you only see it change.
For good measure, we also change the app's themethat means its accent colours and the rest. Next stop is to change the toolbar at the top of the app, and we can apparently animate it! Exciting!

Theme up the navigation
- Colour app bar and status bar, and transition them according to the currently selected item - Lighten the background highlight on the currently selected item
Took a lot longer than you might think, because it's really confusing to deal with status bars and the rest. I first experimented with setting a padding on the toolbar at the top of the screen, but this messed things up when I turned on immersive mode/expanded desktop.
The way to solve it, eventually, was to transition the colours with the toolbar. Apparently Android can take care of the status bar colour just fine without you having to set a darker variant. The other thing to remember was that I had to call `drawerLayout .invalidate()` _after_ I set the status bar colour, to refresh the view.

Implement perspective switching
- Add a flexible `getContexts()`, `getFolders()` and `getTasks()` method for retrieving entries from the database given specified selections and arguments - Re-implement current data model getters using this function - Add getters for tasks that're currently in the inbox, are top level projects, or flagged - Rename `TaskAdapter` to `ListAdapter`, and adapt it to any item (not just tasks) (semi-done) - Vary the items picked up by the ListFragment depending on arguments passed by the calling function (will need to change again for nested lists) - Set up toolbar and navbar in `MainActivity` in their own subroutines - Switch between fragments on menu item selection - Show a progress spinner in the interim - Correctly set `colorAccent` for the spinner colour
The navigation menu from previous updates now does more than just change the colour, it changes between different OmniFocus perspectives, as represented by android Fragments (like a cross between a View and an Activity). Effectively, when you click on an item in the sidebar, the current view will fade out, a progress spinner will fade in, and then fade out again when the new Fragment is ready to show up.
One of the bigger problems with this was working out the UX that Google uses in their Inbox app, which switches fragments and uses a coloured toolbar in a similar way. By default when switching fragments, you switch immediately on press, which is a jarring and non-animated transition. It's also really laggy.
Instead, I realised that Google fade out on click, and fade in once the drawer has closed (while also displaying a spinner as it loads the content). This solution seemed to work fairly well for me, and it creates a smooth and comfortable transition between views.
The next steps are a little more confusing: I need to be able to implement composite lists of Tasks, Contexts and Folders, and display them in each contextright now it breaks when we select 'Contexts' and doesn't show top-level Folders. This will be a challenge, particularly because they have to use the same adapter for the whole list, but I'm sure I'll figure it out (more like, I _have_ to figure it out).

Rewrite selections with string constants
Following the practices outlined in the SDD course, I replaced a lot of hardcoded strings in the Data Model Helper with constants that hold their string content. This means it's easier to write new code in this module, and also make changing something in the code very easy.

Allow different types of view in list
- Rename 'Entry' to 'Entries' in the database contract to avoid conflict - Add some more SQL shorthands to the data model helper - Get a readable database instead of a writable one when all we need to do is read from it (in the data model) - Generalise all returns from the data model to `List<Entry>` - Add the 'No Context' context to the list of top level contexts - Add a `getTopLevelFolders()` method to the data model - Add folders to the `getTopLevelProjects()` method - Update folder child counts in the RecursiveColumnUpdater - Update the available children count in the context updater - Implement `Comparable` in `Entry`, which compares by rank - Extract ViewHolders for Tasks, Folders and Contexts - Implement multiple ViewTypes and corresponding logic in the List Adapter - Add Due Soon and Overdue backgrounds to the Task list item - Oh man
So I know this requires a huge explanation, but it's almost 1am and I need to get some sleep. Plus, I don't think I can write and make much sense at the same time right now. But let's give it a try because I wanna be done with this for the weekend.
Because OmniFocus mixes its lists up, such that we can often see a Folder and a Task in the same list, we also need to mirror this functionality on Android. It's crucial that we can see everything the same way.
On Android, all we have to do is implement different View Types in the RecyclerView, which helps us instantiate new ViewHolders as we need them, with different types depending on what we want to display. In the ListAdapter, we look ahead (using the object's position) at what type it'll be, and generate a ViewHolder based on that, using one of the lovely views and classes we have.
In future, this will need to adapt to whether the task has children or is a project or whatnot, too. Keep an eye out.
Once this is done, it's not too difficult to just take a list of entries, split them up by type, and add each type to the ViewHolder it wants dynamically. Which is what we do.
The problems struck, I think, when I wanted to implement new things, like Folders. The chief one I dealt with just then was getting the folders to display counts of their children. This is tricky because of the rules around folders and projects:
1. A folder can hold other folders 2. A folder can hold projects 3. Projects cannot hold other projects
So the way to solve this while maintaining some efficiency was to have each project update its parent's (which must be a folder or nothing) child counts with its own. But we do this with a simple dictionary of folder IDs and child counts. Then, we iterate through each item in that dictionary and do the same until there are none left, adding items along the way. Finally, we take each ID in that list and update its child counts in the database.
This saves energy because we don't have to count any new items, just push old counts up the stack. There's probably a quicker way to do it. I don't care right now; I need to sleep. Have a nice weekend.

Add empty state
When a list is empty, it's important to let the user know the app hasn't broken and is just showing them an empty view. For that reason, we use empty statesplaceholder views in the background of the list, which are activated if there aren't any list items.
The new code checks the numbers of items in the RecyclerView on creation, and if that number is 0, then it displays a pretty simple logo and message to let the user know. The UI on this section isn't final, but it likely won't change before the submission date.

Add rows for projects and nested tasks
In OmniFocus, projects and nested tasks (i.e. tasks with child tasks) should display differently, because they're containers of tasks instead of tasks themselves, and display in different contexts (this time, I use 'context' in the traditional English sense).
A project displays exactly like a folder, with a 'remaining' count + an 'overdue' and 'due soon' count. The code is pretty much cut-and-paste and isn't going to change for the moment, but I kept it separate because I think they'll need to be separate things in the future.
A nested task displays like a hybrid of the two, with an 'x remaining' counter but also a due date. For this reason, I cut off the overdue/due soon counters because they'd fill the view. When I re-implement them, I'll likely structure it like the iOS OmniFocus app, which uses dots.
Finally, I also moved the ViewHolder binding classes (i.e. setting up the fields with the given task/context/folder) into the ViewHolders themselves, which cleans up `ListAdapter`.

Fix date view problems in Nested Task Holder
Only, I wish they were the only problems. At the very least, I'm gonna have to rewrite the `RecursiveColumnUpdater`, because I'm struggling with hierarchical database structures and it turns out I actually need to count all the children of every object anyway.

Made the recursive column updater more hacky
But hey, at least it works, right? Also, I threw in some buttons to synchronise and refresh the database in the top toolbar for good measure/easy access. They're buggy and will freeze up your UI, but they're there.

Discolour unavailable tasks
In normal OmniFocus, the user wants to be able to skim-read a list and understand as much as they can, because they're a power user and love that sort of stuff. This is why a task that isn't 'available' (i.e. blocked or completed) is greyed out, which is what I just did.
Now onto traversing the big list of tasks/projects/contexts/folders!

Enable full tree traversal
- Add methods to `DataModelHelper` for getting the appropriate children of an entry - Allow 'No Context' to be selected and displayed - Add a new initialiser to `ListFragment` that appropriately gets the data for an individual item - Reenable `OnListFragmentInteractionListener` and implement - Enable touch ripples in the RecyclerView, and convert margins to padding to suit - Use `FragmentTransaction.replace()` instead of removing, to remove all fragments - Change the default theme in `MainActivity` to the red theme (given that most users will start on the Forecast perspective, and not need to see the transition from purple.
The basic viewing app is almost complete! I've come a _long_ way today in putting this together, and now the user can entirely traverse the project and context treesstarting from the base elements and reaching whatever they need to (provided it isn't completed, in which case it's hidden).
The only real step I need to take now is to build the detail views in the list, and I'll have a rudimentary but fully-functional viewer app. Then I'll have to worry about editing, then syncing back up, so what I've decided is that from here I'll try to skip the little details, like animations between screens and fancy colouring, until the app is complete. I don't need those UI flourishes for the assessment, but I will need them for market, and I'm lucky that those are two separate stages in this process.
So I'm going to try and do as much as I can, as quickly as I can, and then move onto the filling in the fancy details later.

Add header rows to child views
Child View: Anything that isn't top-level, i.e. showing the children of a parent Header Row: A row displaying the currently selected parent as an item which can then itself be edited when you tap on it
- Edit sorting logic for Entries to accommodate for header rows - Move ViewHolders - Fade out inactive contexts - Add internal documentation to ViewHolder bindings

Optimise ViewGroup hierarchy
In Android, it's a bad idea to have a lot of ViewGroups as children of each other in a neverending stack extending forever into eternity and the abyss. This is just a quick patch that removes a couple of the poorly-developed layouts and aligns everything according to best practices.

Create basic Detail View
# Important Update I've decided that for the purposes of this assignment, I'm not going to complete a fully syncing OmniFocus application, just a viewer. The whole thing is going to take up far too much of my time, and I won't be able to get that done by August without failing the rest of my subjects.
From now until the due date, I'm going to complete the detail viewer, and add a notification system. I'll also need to implement an automatic syncing routine with that, and there'll probably be other stuff on the way. Once that's done, I'll add some simple finishing touches, and complete the rest of the project once school's out.
It's been really fun so far and I'm looking forward to where this is going. It doesn't just look like a sample project anymore, but instead it really feels like an app I'd use on a semi-regular basis. Once I get some more stuff into it, hopefully that'll only get stronger.
# Changelist - Make all data model items Parcelable - Appropriately handle null dates in the parceling process with new methods - Rename the various fields in the `ViewHolder`s to `entry` - Add a `DetailActivity` for displaying task/context/project details - Change the colour of `DetailActivity`'s app bar depending on where it was launched from (to maintain visual continuity). - Replace `EditText` with `TextInputEditText` for better support - Perform null checks for UI elements - Get the toolbar and drawer layout in `MainActivity` if they're null - Colour the `TextInputLayout` in the toolbar of `DetailActivity` appropriately
# Explanation This change took significantly longer than it needed to. The main reason for this is the way that Android messes around with the status bar and app layouts. Suffice to say I was not happy.
In a `DrawerLayout`, Android appropriately determines that you want the navigation drawer to display underneath the status bar, and extends the UI below it appropriately. This extension includes the toolbar.
Inexplicably, it doesn't do this for any other type of layout. So I spent a few hours trying to figure out what was actually going on with my UI, which was difficult because I had no idea what to search for and my internet was slow because I'd inadvertently downloaded a botnet. Or maybe it was just slow because it slows down sometimesI'm really not sure.
The solution, eventually, was to set the background colour of the view to be the same as the toolbar, so it looks like the toolbar extends below the status bar. Then we set the background of the rest of the view (underneath the toolbar) to be the normal android background (which I think is white). That way, we get the same effect as before, but without having to define a new status bar colour (because it doesn't tint your colours automatically).

Fix small bugs
- Fix a crash where `ViewHolder`s had null entries - Pass the Theme ID to the `DetailActivity` instead of the Menu ID - Make the `DetailActivity`'s toolbar hint depend on the type of entry being shown - Disable editing of the name text

Flight of the Navigator
# Changelog - Add methods for getting context and project names (given ids) - Add new fields to `Task` for context and project names - Fill those fields with the methods - Remove deprecated and messy `getContextNameMap()` function - Add a fragment to the `DetailActivity` to display a list of details - Vary the contents of this fragment depending on the type being shown - Rename a bunch of icons - Make the 'refresh' and 'server' icons white to fit - Add a huge number of layouts for the `DetailFragment`
# IT WORKS! :D After what I'm pretty sure is actually 12 hours of programming today, I think we've legitimately completed a fully-functional OmniFocus navigator. In effect, so long as you don't mind not seeing notifications, notes, attachments and a detailed understanding of the repetitions of the task, and you're happy to manually synchronise it, you can fully browse your OmniFocus library on Android.
Provided you get the .apk off me (which I'm happy to distribute once I figure out howI think there are a few OmniFocus users with Android in our class who might be interested).
Not less than half a day after deciding I was going to cut the project short, I've pretty much met 90% of my target. That's exciting.
Tomorrow, once I've slept, I'll post some screenshots or a video or something. It's looking really nice, and I put a fair bit of attention to detail into this latest list.
:sushi:

Implemented decryption
For this update, I wrote an OmniFocus file decrypter based on the mdoel that OmniGroup wrote in Python. It took a number of days and was one of the heftier parts of the project, particularly considering I had little idea on how to use Java in the ways I wanted to.
But, eventually, we got there. This update adds a number of minor UI changes (including the removal of the `Nearby` menu item, since it's no implemented), and the addition of this routine. It's not perfect and will probably throw errors and have a number of security holesand let's just hope nobody tries to use it with an older version of OmniFocusbut it works for my database on various phones/tablets so that should do for now.

Move sync to background, rewrite parser
The synchronisation loop has been moved out of its original class and into a `SyncAdapter`, which is a more appropriate Android loop and allows us to correctly handle synchronisation (instead of manually / called whenever I want it called). This was basically the last step of this project, once I add the stuff that gets it calling the sync loop automatically, and displaying a spinner on MainActivity whenever the user is syncing.
Also, when doing that, I found that the XML parser was broken. Instead of trying to save XMLPullParser, which is honestly the most horrifying tool I've had to use during this project, I switched to the w3c DOM classes, which work a lot betteralthough required a lot of finnicky rewriting. On top of that, Omni changed a lot of the sync types, which made this a lot harder. But lo, it was finished too.
Now to finish up syncing...

Swipe to refresh
- Add swipe to refresh spinner - Change spinner colour based on perspective - Add a sync broadcaster (to tell when syncs are done) - Show spinner if sync is in progress - Remove old menu icons for manual syncing - Change empty state text (better internal help)
In a moment, I'll set up automatic syncing using our background syncer. I'm impressed at how easy it is to use a sync adapter once it's been setup. These code changes were actually not that tiresome to implement, which is welcome.

SDD hand-in done
- Close leaking SQL cursors - Test for accounts before loading swipeLayout - Fix bug where recyclerView would stay invisible after load (took me AGES) - Update spinner if actively syncing - Send DetailActivity intents back to DetailActivity - Correctly send LoginActivity result to MainActivity - Correctly receive results and start sync - Register periodic syncs and turn on automatic syncs - Increase minimum SDK version to prevent untested code from working on old platforms
This should be the final version of the application before hand-in on 19/8. I've tested it on my phone and tablet running 5.1, and the new sync loop totally works. And it also lets the user know when we're syncing! Plus there's enough internal help to fill the requirements as far as I'm willing to go.
This is excitingas soon as I figure out how to export an APK, I'll upload it. Wouldn't hurt to test this.

Correctly pass Context to AccountManagerHelper
- Update SDK and compilation sources to API 24 (Android 7.0 Nougat) - Pass Context to `AccountManagerHelper` - Reorder the arguments passed to `DownloadFileTask`
In the previous version, `AccountManagerHelper` relied on a context saved in `MainActivity` to run. This broke when a background sync was triggered, because the app was no longer open and thus the context was inaccessible. In this version, the context is retrieved from the sync adapter and sent to the account manager. In other places where the account manager was used, the context is now correctly passed to it natively. This is the more sensible way of running the code.
I have left the `context` field in `MainActivity` because certain classes still rely on it. However, none of these classes need to run in the background and should always be able to access MainActivity's context, so I don't see any harms arising. This will obviously be fixed before a full release.

Correctly pass Context to AccountManagerHelper
- Update SDK and compilation sources to API 24 (Android 7.0 Nougat) - Pass Context to `AccountManagerHelper` - Reorder the arguments passed to `DownloadFileTask`
In the previous version, `AccountManagerHelper` relied on a context saved in `MainActivity` to run. This broke when a background sync was triggered, because the app was no longer open and thus the context was inaccessible. In this version, the context is retrieved from the sync adapter and sent to the account manager. In other places where the account manager was used, the context is now correctly passed to it natively. This is the more sensible way of running the code.
I have left the `context` field in `MainActivity` because certain classes still rely on it. However, none of these classes need to run in the background and should always be able to access MainActivity's context, so I don't see any harms arising. This will obviously be fixed before a full release.
